texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: aliases:
texts.text: aliases:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: /2007/02/11/bulk-ip-update-in-plesk/
texts.text: /2007/02/11/bulk-ip-update-in-plesk/

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: plesk
texts.text: plesk

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's lots of situations where you'd want to use a bulk IP change in Plesk:
texts.text: There's lots of situations where you'd want to use a bulk IP change in Plesk:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Server is moving and needs to change IP's
texts.text: Server is moving and needs to change IP's

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: An IP is the destination for some type of DDOS attack
texts.text: An IP is the destination for some type of DDOS attack

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: An IP needs to be removed from the server
texts.text: An IP needs to be removed from the server

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: So how do you shift tons of domains from one IP to another without spending hours in Plesk clicking and clicking? Do the following instead:
texts.text: So how do you shift tons of domains from one IP to another without spending hours in Plesk clicking and clicking? Do the following instead:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Get into MySQL and find out which IP you're moving from and to:
texts.text: Get into MySQL and find out which IP you're moving from and to:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
mysql -u admin -p`cat /etc/psa/.psa.shadow`
mysql> select * from IP_Addresses;
texts.text:
mysql -u admin -p`cat /etc/psa/.psa.shadow`
mysql> select * from IP_Addresses;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You should see a printout of all of the available IP's on the server. Make a note of the "id" of the IP you're moving from and to. In this example, here's what we're doing:
texts.text: You should see a printout of all of the available IP's on the server. Make a note of the "id" of the IP you're moving from and to. In this example, here's what we're doing:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we can start shifting the physically hosted domains over in the database:
texts.text: Now we can start shifting the physically hosted domains over in the database:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: mysql> update hosting set ip_address_id=3 where ip_address_id=2;
texts.text: mysql> update hosting set ip_address_id=3 where ip_address_id=2;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We also need to change the domains that are set up for standard or frame forwarding:
texts.text: We also need to change the domains that are set up for standard or frame forwarding:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: mysql> update forwarding set ip_address_id=3 where ip_address_id=2;
texts.text: mysql> update forwarding set ip_address_id=3 where ip_address_id=2;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we're stuck with the arduous task of updating DNS records. Plesk is kind enough to store this data in four different ways:
texts.text: Now we're stuck with the arduous task of updating DNS records. Plesk is kind enough to store this data in four different ways:

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: Everything domain related is now moved, but the clients that the domains belong to might not have this new IP address in their IP pool. First, we need to find out our component ID's from the repository table (which generally should be the same as the IP_Addresses.id column, but not always)
texts.text: Everything domain related is now moved, but the clients that the domains belong to might not have this new IP address in their IP pool. First, we need to find out our component ID's from the repository table (which generally should be the same as the IP_Addresses.id column, but not always)

texts.label: code
texts.orig: mysql> SELECT clients.login, IP_Addresses.ip_address,Repository.* FROM clients LEFT JOIN Repository ON clients.pool_id = Repository.rep_id LEFT JOIN IP_Addresses ON Repository.component_id = IP_Addresses.id;
texts.text: mysql> SELECT clients.login, IP_Addresses.ip_address,Repository.* FROM clients LEFT JOIN Repository ON clients.pool_id = Repository.rep_id LEFT JOIN IP_Addresses ON Repository.component_id = IP_Addresses.id;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For this example, we'll pretend that the output consists of 2's for these clients. We can flip the IP's in the clients' IP pools by running the following:
texts.text: For this example, we'll pretend that the output consists of 2's for these clients. We can flip the IP's in the clients' IP pools by running the following:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: mysql> update Repository set component_id=3 where component_id=2;
texts.text: mysql> update Repository set component_id=3 where component_id=2;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now that everything is changed in Plesk's database, it's time to change up the Apache and BIND configuration files. Luckily, this can be done pretty easily with Plesk's command line tools:
texts.text: Now that everything is changed in Plesk's database, it's time to change up the Apache and BIND configuration files. Luckily, this can be done pretty easily with Plesk's command line tools:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /usr/local/psa/admin/bin/websrvmng -av
# mysql -Ns -uadmin -p`cat /etc/psa/.psa.shadow` -D psa -e 'select name from domains' | awk '{print "/usr/local/psa/admin/sbin/dnsmng update " $1 }' | sh
texts.text:
# /usr/local/psa/admin/bin/websrvmng -av
# mysql -Ns -uadmin -p`cat /etc/psa/.psa.shadow` -D psa -e 'select name from domains' | awk '{print "/usr/local/psa/admin/sbin/dnsmng update " $1 }' | sh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All that is left is to force Apache and BIND to pick up the new configuration:
texts.text: All that is left is to force Apache and BIND to pick up the new configuration:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /etc/init.d/httpd reload
# /etc/init.d/named reload
texts.text:
# /etc/init.d/httpd reload
# /etc/init.d/named reload

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Just wait for the DNS records to propagate and you should be all set! The instructions are cumbersome, I know, but it's easier than clicking for-ev-er.
texts.text: Just wait for the DNS records to propagate and you should be all set! The instructions are cumbersome, I know, but it's easier than clicking for-ev-er.
